comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -28,7 +28,7 @@ liboqs-dotnet
 
 This solution implements a .NET wrapper in C# for the C OQS library. It contains the following projects:
 
-- **dotnetOQS**: A C# class library targeting .NET Core 1.1, wrapping the master branch of the OQS library.
+- **dotnetOQS**: A C# class library targeting .NET Standard 1.2 and 2.0, wrapping the master branch of the OQS library.
comment.body: Why two version? We should list the minimum version we support; if it's 1.2, then I'd only leave 1.2. Or is the code different if you are targeting 2.0?

pull_request.title: Allow Linux and MacOs to consume this wrapper without issues
pull_request.body:
This pull request contains codes that allow Linux and macOS to consume this wrapper.

The changes are:
1. Addition of Lib_OQS_KEM_* and Lib_OQS_SIG_* methods for both Linux and macOS. (They are essentially pointed to the original signature in DllImport)
2. Changed target frameworks to netstandard1.2 and netstandard2.0 allowing different version of .Net Core and .Net framework version to use this library. (netstandard1.2 is added for compatibility with the existing test case for netcoreapp1.1)
3. Removed prebuild event for all projects except test case to allow other OS to execute the new dotnet cli commands.
4. Addition of some useful scripts that can be used for reference for building this project. (Consist of windows and macOS variants)

#2 #10

comment.body: It would be nice to avoid these branching calls all over the program. Would that go away if the DLL was named something different?

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -28,7 +28,7 @@ liboqs-dotnet
 
 This solution implements a .NET wrapper in C# for the C OQS library. It contains the following projects:
 
-- **dotnetOQS**: A C# class library targeting .NET Core 1.1, wrapping the master branch of the OQS library.
+- **dotnetOQS**: A C# class library targeting .NET Standard 1.2 and 2.0, wrapping the master branch of the OQS library.
comment.body:
The code is the same for those two target. However, the range of support is slightly different and the build size.

The main reason for having 2.0 is the reduced number of dependencies required when building an application. In that case, the app is smaller in size compared to 1.2. (Though the range of support is for newer .net core implementation)

comment.body: Yeah, the file name limitations currently. Until there is a better way to resolve this, I am unable to point a different file name during a compile time constant for DllImport
